events.summary: Nikolai Andreyevich Rimsky-Korsakov made his grand entrance into the world in Tikhvin, starting his lifelong love affair with music and naval adventures. It’s safe to say he was destined to be a big fish in a small pond, or rather a maritime maestro!

With a childhood fantasy of ocean exploits fueled by his older brother's adventures, he decided to trade piano scales for naval maps. He attended the School for Mathematical and Navigational Sciences, proving that even composers can navigate complex waters—just not always in rhythm!

After enduring the rigorous tutelage of Balakirev and a two-year ocean cruise devoid of any musical stimulation, Rimsky-Korsakov finally took center stage with his symphony's debut performance under Balakirev's watchful eye, proving that the sea didn't drown his talent after all!

In a plot twist where the student becomes the master, Rimsky-Korsakov took on the role of a professor at the Saint Petersburg Conservatory. Who knew that teaching harmony would prove to be as satisfying as composing it? Think of it as conducting a classroom symphony!

Rimsky-Korsakov wrapped up his magnum opus, Scheherazade, weaving in tales and exotic harmonies. It was like his own personal storytelling concert where you didn’t even need a ticket to dream of Arabian nights!

Not content with simply composing, Rimsky-Korsakov decided to immortalize his orchestration wisdom in a textbook, demonstrating that he was not just a composer but also a certified 'orchestra whisperer'. Talk about leaving a musical legacy!

Rimsky-Korsakov became thick as thieves with the members of The Five, where they critiqued each other's works with the intensity of old friends arguing over the best borscht recipe. He even had a duet-piano moment with Mussorgsky—they would play music, Mussorgsky would sing, and they shared opinions that mismatched the tastes of established composers like a pair of mismatched socks.

events.event: Professor at the Saint Petersburg Conservatory
events.summary: Rimsky-Korsakov secured a cushy teaching gig as Professor of Practical Composition and Instrumentation, leading the Orchestra Class while decked out in full naval uniform—as if he could compose with a side of authority! His knowledge of musical theory was like a sailor navigating with a map of the stars and a can of beans; yet he still managed to give his students quite the show!

In a delightful twist of life, Rimsky-Korsakov married Nadezhda Purgold, who had a sharp musical mind to match her beauty and charm. Their union was the kind that had Mussorgsky serving as the best man, proving that even composers have friends willing to witness their big day. Together, they raised seven kids, which must have sounded like a full orchestra of their own!

Rimsky-Korsakov jumped ship to become the Inspector of Naval Bands, a role that had him strutting around as a civilian while still on the navy's payroll. Goodbye, military uniform! Hello, music! He mixed inspections with musical exploration, proving that even bandmasters could use a good dose of orchestration wisdom.

Amidst the chaos of band inspections, Rimsky-Korsakov decided it was time to put pen to paper and write a textbook on orchestration. His studies made their way into the book, ensuring that future generations wouldn’t have to decipher the mysteries of orchestral music with a magic 8-ball. Talk about leaving a legacy!

Resurrecting the works of Mikhail Glinka became a purposeful hobby for Rimsky-Korsakov, who helped ensure Glinka's music saw the light of day again. It was part musical rehab, part homage—like dusting off a classic vintage vinyl and hoping your friends won’t judge your taste in music. This project shaped the future of Russian music and showcased Rimsky-Korsakov's commitment to honoring the greats!

Rimsky-Korsakov decided it was high time to add 'opera composer' to his résumé, influenced by a delightful short story by Nikolai Gogol. Thanks to his supportive wife, Nadezhda, who insisted he'd better get on with it, he dove headfirst into the musical depths and emerged with a completed opera in a matter of months.

Rimsky-Korsakov took the genius of Russian music to the masses, co-founding concerts with Mitrofan Belyayev and dragging along some illustrious friends. He cheekily used these events to showcase his own works while simultaneously coaxing himself out of a creative slump. It was like winning a game of musical poker and revealing his own winning cards.

The great Tchaikovsky waltzed into Rimsky-Korsakov's life, and instead of a standard handshake, they exchanged letters and engaged in a captivating musical love fest. Despite some jealous feels about Tchaikovsky's rising star, they became fast friends, which made for quite the lively social scene!

events.event: Attended Wagner's Der Ring des Nibelungen
events.summary: Rimsky-Korsakov found himself utterly bewitched by Wagner's orchestral wizardry during a performance of The Ring in Saint Petersburg, leading him to ditch his previous writing style like last season's fashion. Henceforth, he decided that composing operas was his newfound calling, much to the delight of his audience!

After a series of unfortunate events, including family health crises that would make a soap opera writer weep, Rimsky-Korsakov hit a rocky patch in his composition career. But fear not! This was just a dramatic build-up before a grand comeback that would put all his previous works to shame!

After Tchaikovsky's timely demise (what a party that could have been!), Rimsky-Korsakov seized the opportunity to write an opera based on Gogol's Christmas Eve. This spark ignited a flurry of creativity, and he soon found himself metaphorically juggling eleven new operas as the clock ticked towards his retirement!

During the revolutionary fervor at the Conservatory, Rimsky-Korsakov donned his superhero cape as he bravely stood up for student rights. Despite the chaotic mess, he sought to mediate and decided to add 'student protector' to his long list of roles. Who knew he'd swap composing for negotiating for a moment?

In an eyebrow-raising twist, Rimsky-Korsakov was dismissed from the Conservatory amid student unrest but decided to teach from home. Clearly, once a teacher, always a teacher, or maybe he just couldn't resist sharing his musical wisdom, even if it meant defying authority!

After his opera 'Kashchey the Immortal' was performed, the audience decided it was a better time for a political demonstration than a concert. This shindig led to an official ban on Rimsky-Korsakov's work, much to the dismay and amusement of many who sent him sympathetic letters, including donations from peasants who probably just wanted to join the fun!

Following a wave of support that saw over 300 students walk out in protest and a plethora of sympathy letters, Rimsky-Korsakov was reinstated with a shiny new director at the helm—clearly, being popular goes a long way in the world of music and academic drama!

After decades of teaching and inspiring students, Rimsky-Korsakov finally decided to retire from the Conservatory, likely to enjoy some peace and quiet—or perhaps to focus on his next big composition without the distractions of student queries like 'But why is it called music?'!

In a grand display of musical camaraderie, Rimsky-Korsakov conducted concerts in Paris that highlighted Russian nationalist music. The success of these concerts didn't just make him popular; it was like giving Russian classical music a significant upgrade in the European scene, almost like a musical rebranding!

Rimsky-Korsakov's long battle with angina took a final bow in 1908, leaving behind an impressive catalog of musical wonders. He passed away at his estate, likely dreaming of orchestral harmonies and knowing he left a legacy that would make future composers raise their eyebrows and pen their own symphonies!

Rimsky-Korsakov taught theory and composition to 250 students, turning them into a veritable army of composers. His teaching style involved a strategic blend of wisdom and the occasional theatrical pause, ensuring that by the end of the term, students were fluent in melody and tired of his voice.

In a move that would make him a magical editor of sorts, Rimsky-Korsakov undertook the task of refining works by The Five after their authors were no longer able to hold their pens. Think of him as a literary fairy godmother, transforming ‘rough drafts’ into full-on orchestral pieces.

Rimsky-Korsakov dived deep into Russian folklore, merging music with the ancient pagan vibes of sun worship. He discovered that folk songs were like the artisanal bread of music – each one layered with history, flavor, and an irresistible charm.

In an effort to immortalize his musical saga, Rimsky-Korsakov penned his autobiography, detailing his creative adventures and insights. It’s as if he wanted to leave behind a treasure map for future composers, marked with ‘X’ for extra genius.
He whipped up a fantastical symphonic suite inspired by 'One Thousand and One Nights', proving that storytelling could happen without a single book in sight.
Rimsky-Korsakov decided to be a sailor. Little did he know it was merely a plot twist in his opera of life; he had a flair for music not for sea shanties.
He teamed up with four other Russian composers to form 'The Five', aiming to make a homegrown style of music, probably while arguing over who gets to wear the coolest hat.
Rimsky-Korsakov brought winter wonderlands to the opera house, proving that frozen princesses sing just as beautifully as sunbaked ones.
He turned from composing to educating, perhaps hoping to turn his students into the next great Russian composers without the use of magic spells.

compositions.title: Concert Fantasia on Russian Themes, Op.33
Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, Op.22
String Quartet in F major, Op.12
Variations on a Theme by Glinka
6 Variations on the Theme B-A-C-H, Op.10
